Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Robotics and Autonomous Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site will train students in research methodology by engaging them in authentic research projects and using a focused approach to promote a sense of belonging in the research community. The participating faculty mentors span the spectrum of cutting-edge research topics in robotics and are well established in their fields. Students will participate in research projects that cross-cut multiple areas of robotics and autonomous systems, including socially assistive robotics, robot learning, networked robotics, and robotics data processing. They will gain research experience in solving some of the most challenging modern robotics and autonomy problems and get exposure to robotics research beyond the scope of the REU site, through seminars by other University of Southern California faculty and external site visits, to aid in planning their next career steps. The intended impact is to have a significant proportion of the REU students go on to graduate school.

The goal of this REU site is to incorporate into the professional research community a cohort of undergraduate student participants from three populations: (1) academically talented students from traditionally underserved colleges and universities, (2) women, and (3) underrepresented minorities. It will use expertise from the USC Viterbi School of Engineering's Center for Engineering Diversity to explicitly promote diversity in the REU student pool. The dual objective is to train carefully selected students in research methodology, and excite them about robotics research by providing a compelling cohort experience. Students will work with faculty mentors and their Ph.D. students, interact with an existing Viterbi School of Engineering Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site, and engage in three relevant external research visits. A rigorous assessment of outcomes is planned. To facilitate the sense of a research cohort and encourage networks, housing will be provided in on-campus apartments, as will additional social programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the REU site was to instill a sense of belonging to the research community into a cohort of undergraduate student participants from three populations: 1. academically talented students from traditionally underserved colleges and universities, 2. women, and 3. underrepresented minorities. Our dual objective was to 1. train carefully selected students in research methodology, and 2. excite them about robotics research by providing a compelling cohort experience. The intended impact was to have a significant proportion of the REU students go on to graduate school, and this was realized.

Students worked with faculty mentors and their PhD students, on real, open-ended research projects. While this presented a significant challenge in a 9-10 week summer program for undergraduate students, especially those who had not previously participated in authentic research projects, a large majority of students in every cohort saw their project come together and felt a great sense of accomplishment by the end of the program.

As is well documented, a personal sense of belonging in the field has a significant effect on the retention of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM. By having greater than 50% URM participants in each cohort, and greater than 50% female faculty mentors in each cohort, students observed a diverse group of researchers, and we were able to instill a sense of belonging to the STEM community.  

At least three students were awarded NSF graduate research fellowships, and one student was selected to attend the 2019 NSF EEC Grantees Conference as an invited REU site participant.

 A significant portion (85% of respondents to a historical survey) stated that the REU Site increased their probability of going to graduate school, and 65% stated it stimulated their interest in a research career.  

External evaluation shows that the REU has the intended impact to significantly affect career and further education choices for women and minorities in STEM fields and to have a substantial proportion of past REU students go on to graduate school and/or professional STEM careers.
